Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of a horse. Head fragment, broken at neck, missing part of muzzle. Appears to have had a rider, with crude hands broken at the wrist above the horses ears. Hollow and possibly mould-made. White coating with traces of black painted details around the eyes and for one pupil. Local red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, rounded quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This crude example resembles a finer Ptolemaic horse figure found at Naukratis (BM GR 1886,0401.1465, dated 2nd to 1st century BC) cited by Fischer as a parallel for a Hellenistic period horses head now at Dresden Museum (1994, 413-4, no. 1102). A Late Period date was found in the Cambridge MCA archive for this, possibly based on original find records. Parallel from Tell Basta in Cairo Museum (CG43485 =TR13/3/22/5= SR5/1839) Fischer, J. 1994. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen. Tübingen, Wasmuth.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.247) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 97, nos 346-351)
